questions.text: After removing the parotid gland, the patient presents with sweating on the cheeks while eating. This reflects aberrant innervation of which nerve?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms reflect aberrant innervation of the auriculotemporal nerve.

The patient experiencing sweating on cheeks while eating, is the symptom of Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

  • It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule.
  • During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands. This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.
  • Management - The symptoms can be treated by subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and use of antiperspirant. Denervation by tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve may be useful.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • The skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus is supplied by T7-T9.
  • The skin around the umbilicus is supplied by T10.
  • The skin below the umbilicus until the suprapubic region is supplied by T11, T12. 
  • The skin around genitalia and upper medial thigh is supplied by L1.

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant was born with a laryngeal defect. CT-scan revealed an ​absence of greater cornu of the hyoid and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Greater horn (greater cornu) and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone are formed from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following joints is known as ‘Peg and Socket’ joint?
questions.solution:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket. 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis (see Table).

Classification of Fibrous joints
Subtype Description Examples
1. Sutures Peculiar to the skull. Bones are separated by a layer of membrane-derived connective tissue.
  • Plane, e.g. internasal suture
  • Serrate, e.g. interparietal suture
  • Squamous, e.g. temporoparietal suture
  • Denticulate, e.g. lambdoid suture
  • Schindylesis type, specialized suture in which a ridged bone fits into a groove on a neighboring bone, e.g. the cleft between the alae of the vomer receives the rostrum of the sphenoid
2. Syndesmosis There is a true fibrous connection between bones.
  • Connected by interosseous ligament, e.g. tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis
  • Connected by a dense fibrous membrane, e.g. posterior region of sacroiliac joint
3. Gomphosis A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections.
  • The tooth in its socket

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the blood-brain barrier?

choices.text: End feet of astrocytes covering the capillary walls

questions.solution:
Capillaries with fenestrations are not part of the blood-brain barrier. 

Blood-brain barrier is constituted by:

  • Capillary endothelium with tight junctions (no fenestrations).
  • Basement membrane of the endothelium.
  • End feet of astrocytes covering the capillary walls.

The barrier permits a selective passage of blood constituents to the nervous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the portal triad of the liver?
questions.solution:
Hepatic vein does not form part of the portal triad.

Portal canals are present at the angular intervals at the periphery of each hepatic lobule. They are filled with connective tissue and form a connective tissue network across the entire liver substance.

Each ‘canal’ consists of

  • A branch of the portal vein
  • A branch of the hepatic artery
  • An interlobular bile duct.

These three structures collectively form a portal triad.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male was diagnosed with a tumor in the right submandibular gland and was posted for surgical removal of the gland and its duct.  During the procedure, which of the following nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Lingual nerve loops around the submandibular duct, and hence is susceptible to injury during the procedures involving the excision of the submandibular gland or its duct.

Damage to the lingual nerve causes loss of sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.

Superficial to the hyoglossus muscle, the submandibular duct lies between lingual and hypoglossal nerves. As it reaches the anterior border of the hyoglossus, it is crossed by the lingual nerve.

The submandibular gland is divided into a larger superficial and smaller deep part by the mylohyoid muscle. They are continuous with each other around the posterior border of mylohyoid.

Important structures related to superficial part are:

  • Facial artery
  • Facial vein
  • Cervical branch of the facial nerve
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Submandibular ganglion
  • Lingual nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Deep lingual vein

Important structures related to the deep part are:

  • Sublingual gland
  • Lingual nerve 
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Deep lingual vein

questions.text: Nerve supply to the muscle marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution: The muscle marked in the above image is the Teres Major and it is supplied by the Lower Subscapular Nerve.

questions.text: Above knee perforators are called as:
questions.solution:
Above knee perforators are called as Dodd veins.

Perforator veins connect the deep and superficial venous systems, allowing the passage of blood in between them. Following are the named perforators of the lower limb:

  • Proximal thigh level perforators- Hunter perforator veins
  • Distal thigh perforators- Dodd perforator veins
  • Below the knee perforators- Boyd perforator veins 
  • Calf level perforators- Cockett perforator veins.

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall on an outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or snuff.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl playing with small magnets suddenly develops breathlessness. Chest X-ray shows an inhaled foreign body in one of the bronchi. Where does the vein supplying the most likely site of obstruction drain into?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario of an inhaled foreign body, it is most likely to lodge into the right bronchus. The right bronchial veins drain to the azygos vein. 

Left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein or left superior intercostal vein.

Clinical significance:

The right principal bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical. This is why an inhaled foreign body is more likely to lodge there. Also, the tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the dura covering the marked region?

choices.text: C2-C3 via cranial nerves X and XII
Cranial nerves VII and IX only

questions.solution:
The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly innervated by C2 and C3 nerves via cranial nerves X and XII. 

These fibers may be distributed by the vagus and hypoglossal nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following artery does not take part in the cruciate anastomosis?
questions.solution:
The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of cruciate anastomosis.

Cruciate anastomosis lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:

  • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
  • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery

The image given below shows the anastomosis around the hip joint.

Note: Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds, or gunshot wounds) can result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
Obturator internus with its fascia forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis.

Muscles forming walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall - obturator internus and the fascia over its upper and inner (pelvic) surface.
  • Posterolateral wall - piriformis
  • Floor - levator ani and coccygeus

questions.text: Which of the following structures form the angle of anteversion?
questions.solution:
The angle of anteversion is formed between the long axis of the cervix and the long axis of the vagina.

The angle of anteflexion which is formed by the body of the uterus and the long axis of the cervix.

When the whole of the uterus leans backwards at an angle to the vagina, it is called retroversion. If the uterus angles backwards in relation to cervix it is called retroflexion.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man complains of weakness of his trunk muscles following a stroke.  While examining the patient, you ask him to perform the following movement. Which of the following muscles is/are being tested here?

choices.text: Ipsilateral external oblique and contralateral internal oblique
Ipsilateral external oblique and internal oblique
Ipsilateral transversus abdominis and internal oblique

questions.solution:
The given image shows lateral flexion of the trunk being performed, which is done by the ipsilateral external oblique (EO) and internal oblique (IO) muscles.

The anterior abdominal wall comprises of 4 muscles:

  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Rectus abdominis

Muscles involved in movements of the trunk include:

Action

Muscles involved

Forward flexion of trunk (lumbar spine)

Rectus abdominis and bilateral IO and EO

Lateral flexion of  the trunk

Ipsilateral IO and EO
Rotation of trunk

Ipsilateral IO and contralateral EO

Tensing the linea alba

Pyramidalis

questions.text: The rounded secretory cells bearing microvilli present in the epithelial lining of the alveoli are _____
questions.solution:
The secretory cells bearing microvilli present in the epithelial lining of the alveoli are the type II pneumocytes.

The cells forming the lining epithelium of alveoli (also called pneumocytes) are mainly of the following types:

  • Type I pneumocytes - large flattened cells which present a very thin diffusion barrier for gases. They are connected to each other by tight junctions.
  • Type II pneumocytes - These are rounded secretory cells bearing microvilli on their free surfaces. These cells secrete the surfactant which decreases the surface tension between the thin alveolar walls, and thus prevents alveoli from collapsing during respiration.
  • Type III alveolar cells (brush cells) - function is not clearly known.

The given image shows a histological section of the lung showing the pneumocytes.

questions.text: Vasopressin secretion is increased by_____
questions.solution:
Vasopressin (ADH) secretion increases in response to decreased ECF volume to bring about water retention to restore the ECF volume.

ADH exerts its antidiuretic effect by acting on the V2 receptors and involves the insertion of aquaporin 2 (AQP2) into the apical (luminal) membranes of the principal cells of the collecting ducts.

Related Pearl: Summary of Stimuli affecting Vasopressin Secretion

Increased vasopressin secretion

Decreased vasopressin secretion

Increased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Decreased ECF volume

Pain, emotions, stress, exercise

Nausea and vomiting

Standing

Angiotensin II

Clofibrate, carbamazepine

Decreased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Increased ECF volume

Alcohol

questions.text: In patients with renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear in the urine. What is the reason behind this?
questions.solution:
In renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear because of its effective molecular diameter. 

Both charge and size selectivity normally prevent virtually all plasma albumin, globulins, and other high-molecular-weight proteins from crossing the glomerular wall. However, if this barrier is disrupted, plasma proteins may leak into the urine.

The molecular diameter of the albumin is only about 6 nanometers, whereas the pores of the glomerular membrane are thought to be about 8 nanometers. In minimal change nephropathy, the negative charges on the basement membrane are lost even before there are noticeable changes in kidney histology. As a result of this loss of negative charges on the basement membranes, some of the lower molecular weight proteins, especially albumin (effective molecular diameter of 7 nm), are filtered and appear in the urine, a condition known as proteinuria or albuminuria.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: All of the following regulates intestinal absorption of iron except:

choices.text: State of iron stores in the body
State of erythropoiesis in bone marrow

questions.solution:
Intestinal absorption of iron is not regulated by the daily loss of iron.

The intestinal absorption of iron is regulated by three factors:

  1. Recent dietary intake of iron
  2. State of the iron stores in the body
  3. State of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

questions.text: The forced expiratory volume in the 1st second (FEV1) curves shown in the figure below were obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be emphysema.

FVC (Forced vital capacity) is the maximum volume of air that can be expired forcefully after maximal inspiration. It is decreased in both restrictive and obstructive diseases

FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) is the fraction of forced vital capacity expired during the first second of forced expiration.

Pulmonary function tests can be used to differentiate between restrictive and obstructive diseases.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, the obstruction in the airways reduces both FEV1 and FVC. However, the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio FEV1/FVC also decreases. The total lung capacity is normal or elevated.
    Ex: Asthma, COPD, Bronchiectasis.
  • In restrictive diseases, the FVC is reduced. However, the patient's airflow is fast initially, which soon levels out with the FVC. As a result, the FEV1/FVC is normal or increased. The total lung capacity is reduced.
    Ex: Pulmonary fibrosis (Tuberculosis), pneumoconiosis, sarcoidosis, kyphosis.

The following graph shows the FVC of restrictive and obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text: Upper Motor Neurons (UMN) include ______
questions.solution:
• Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons.
  • Corticospinal tract contain a population of large myelinated fibers with a mean diameter of 16 micrometers. These fibers originate from giant pyramidal cells, called Betz cells, that are found only in the primary motor cortex.

questions.text: Tight junctions are not seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Tight junctions are not seen in cardiac muscle. 

Tight junctions form a water-tight seal between cells. They are characteristically seen in the following:

  • Intestinal mucosa
  • Renal tubules
  • Choroid plexus
  • Sertoli cells

Functions of tight junctions are:

  • Prevents the diffusion of macromolecules between cells.
  • Maintains cell polarity.
  • Seals the paracellular pathway.

questions.text: What is the effect on membrane when extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased?
questions.solution:
When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increased negativity of RMP.

RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusion depends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration of K+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+ rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell more negative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving the membrane hyperpolarised.

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g.,neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text: The most distinguishing feature between skeletal muscle and smooth muscle is ______
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But, troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: Oxytocin causes all except_____
questions.solution: Lactogenesis is caused by prolactin, while milk ejection is caused by oxytocin.

questions.text: Hormone(s) required during puberty_____
questions.solution:
GH, leptin, and testosterone are all required for the onset of puberty.

The onset of puberty is marked by enhanced androgenic activity.

The growth spurt of adolescent males is influenced by a complex interplay between androgens, growth hormone (GH), nutrition, and genetic factors.

Leptin, the satiety-producing hormone secreted by fat cells, maybe the link between body weight and puberty.

questions.text: Prostaglandins in semen are secreted by ________
questions.solution:
Prostaglandins in semen are secreted by Seminal vesicle.

The seminal vesicles secrete fluid that is rich in fructose, citrate, prostaglandins, and fibrinogen.

The prostaglandins present in the seminal fluid may assist in fertilization in two ways:

  • Prostaglandins react with cervical mucus to make it more penetrable by sperm.
  • Prostaglandins induce peristaltic contractions in the female reproductive tract (i.e., the uterus and fallopian tubes) to propel the sperm up the tract.

questions.text: What does the “a” wave in JVP represent?
questions.solution:
The "a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction.

Waves of JVP :

  • a- Atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles.
  • c- Isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge.
  • x- Fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to the pull of valve leaflets.
  • v- Venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y- Passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of blood from the right atrium.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient is able to recognize a person by name but not face. The lesion, in this case, is in_____
questions.solution:
This condition is prosopagnosia, which occurs in the lesions of the inferior temporal lobe.

In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals (i.e non-dominant inferior temporal lobe).

Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces. Patients with this abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. How­ever, they cannot identify the familiar people by seeing their faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemi­sphere is primary.

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
The site of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while illuminating the normal half shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumours of the optic thalamus.

The optic tracts contain both visual and pupillomotor fibres. The visual fibres terminate in the lateral geniculate body, but the pupillary fibres leave the optic tract anterior to the lateral geniculate body to terminate in the pretectal nuclei.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except:

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU) and tryptophan deficiency is not a feature of this disorder. PKU is caused by the deficiency of an enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis. Ferric chloride test is also used as a screening test for PKU. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard investigation.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: Alpha helix and beta pleated sheet are examples of the ______ structure of a protein.
questions.solution:
Alpha helix and beta-pleated sheets are examples of the secondary structure of a protein. The polypeptide chains form a regular arrangement of amino acids that are near each other in a linear sequence. These arrangements are termed as secondary structure of the polypeptide.

Examples:

  • Alpha helix
  • Beta sheet
  • Beta turn/bend

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Where does the Krebs–Henseleit cycle cycle take place?
questions.solution:
Ornithine cycle/Krebs–Henseleit cycle/Urea cycle occurs in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria.

The reactions that take place both in the cytoplasm and mitochondria are:

  • H: Heme synthesis
  • U: Urea cycle
  • G: Gluconeogenesis
  • Pathway: Pyrimidine synthesis

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea, namely ammonia and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  • Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  • Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  • Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  • Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  • Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe, and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  • Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A neonate presents with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. Her urine has a peculiar burnt sugar odor due to an excess of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following is unlikely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). Lysine is not a branched-chain amino acid and hence is unlikely to be elevated.

Branched-chain amino acids are:

  • Valine (V)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Leucine (L)

MSUD is due to the deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC), leading to the formation of branched-chain amino acids and their toxic by-products (ketoacids) in the blood and urine. There is a peculiar odor of burnt sugar found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

questions.text:
Which of the following are essential fatty acids?
  1. Linoleic acid
  2. γ-Linolenic acid
  3. α-Linolenic acid
  4. Oleic acid
questions.solution:
Linoleic acid and α-Linolenic acid are essential fatty acid.

Essential fatty acid refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Arachidonic acid and γ-Linolenic acid are semi-essential fatty acids since they can be derived from essential fatty acids.

questions.text: Each cycle of β-oxidation produces ___________.
questions.solution:
One cycle of β-oxidation of fatty acids produces 1 FADH2, 1 NADH, and 1 acetyl-CoA.

  • FADH2 is formed in the reaction catalyzed by acyl CoA dehydrogenase.
  • NADH is formed in the reaction catalyzed by β-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase
  • In each cycle of β-oxidation, the terminal two carbons are cleaved as acetyl CoA starting at carboxyl end.

Thus, the overall reaction of each cycle of β-oxidation can be summarized as follows:

(Cn)acyl CoA + FAD + NAD++ H2O + CoA → (Cn-2)acyl CoA + FADH2 + NADH + Acetyl CoA +H+

questions.text: Which of the following organs cannot catabolize the glycerol component of triacylglycerol?
questions.solution:
The brain cannot catabolize the glycerol component of triacylglycerol due to the lack of the enzyme glycerol kinase.

The utilization of glycerol depends upon whether the tissue has the enzyme glycerol kinase, found in the liver, kidney, intestine, brown adipose tissue and the lactating mammary gland.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man comes to  OPD for a follow-up visit. His serum LDL level is high. He is started on a lipid-lowering drug that acts on the rate-limiting step of cholesterol synthesis. Which of the following is the site of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis.

HMG-CoA reductase is inhibited by the statin group of drugs (e.g. Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin, Pravastatin, etc.) which are widely used as lipid-lowering agents.

Regulation of HMG CoA reductase:

Activity increased by Activity decreased by
Insulin Glucagon, glucocorticoids
Thyroid hormone Cholesterol, mevalonate
  Dietary cholesterol
  Statins

Glucagon and glucocorticoids repress the transcription of HMG CoA reductase via sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the effect of substrate concentration on the rate of reaction?

choices.text: As substrate concentration increases, the initial velocity of the reaction increases until it reaches a maximum value (Vmax)
The substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half maximum is called Km
The Michaelis-Menten equation says that initial reaction velocity (Vi) = Vmax [S]/ Km+[S]
The plot of reaction velocity against substrate concentration is linear

questions.solution:
The plot of reaction velocity against substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

For a typical enzyme, as the substrate concentration increases, initial velocity (Vi) increases until it reaches a maximum value of Vmax. With further increase in the substrate concentration [S], the enzyme is said to be “saturated” with the substrate and the velocity remains the same. Hence, the shape of the curve that relates to the velocity of the reaction to substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates mathematically the relationship between Vi and [S] i.e,

Vi = Vmax ×[S]/Km+[S]

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which Vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2).

questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by blocking the transportation of ADP and ATP?
questions.solution:
Atractyloside is a drug, which inhibits the process of oxidative phosphorylation by preventing the transportation of ADP into, and ATP out of, the mitochondria.

questions.text: All of the following statements about glucokinase are true in comparison to hexokinase, except ________.

choices.text: It is present in most tissues

questions.solution:
Glucokinase is present only in the liver and the beta cells of the pancreas, not most of the tissues.

Glucose is the only cellular substrate that can be phosphorylated by glucokinase. 

Glucokinase has a higher Vmax and a higher Km value than hexokinase. This means it requires a higher concentration of glucose for half saturation.

Characteristics Hexokinase Glucokinase
Tissue distribution Most tissues Liver and beta cells of the pancreas
Km Low High

Vmax

 Low High
Inhibition by G6P Yes No
Inducible No Inducible
Clinical significance Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia Less activity in diabetes mellitus
Biological significance Involved in maintaining intracellular glucose concentration  Involved in maintaining blood glucose concentration

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

Image: Myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing

(A) Normal muscle

(B) - McArdle's disease

questions.text: Which of the following is an allosteric inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Allosteric inhibitors of PDH enzyme complex :

  • NADH
  • Acetyl CoA
  • ATP

questions.text: All of the following are signs and symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, except ______
questions.solution:
Vitamin A toxicity causes increased intracranial pressure.

The accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins producing hypervitaminosis.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

  • CNS: symptoms of raised intracranial pressure(pseudotumor cerebri) such as headache, nausea, vomiting, blurring of vision
  • Liver: hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia
  • Bones: thickening of the long bones(bony exostosis), hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification
  • Dermatological: dryness, exfoliative dermatitis, alopecia
  • Teratogenesis: Pregnant women should not ingest excessive quantities as it can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin(13 cis retinoic acid) is a drug which is teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: What is a primary transcript?

choices.text: RNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction
RNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction

questions.solution:
The RNA product, which is synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction, is the primary transcript. The primary transcripts are generated by RNA polymerase II.

The longest primary transcript is produced by the dystrophin gene.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following:
questions.solution:
Restriction endonucleases can act on AAGCTT. 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence, such as:

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'
3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

A palindromic sequence is a sequence which reads the same backwards and forwards.

 Restriction endonucleases enzymes are routinely used for DNA modification in laboratories, and they are a vital tool in molecular cloning.

questions.text: Folate trap occurs due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Folate trap occurs in the deficiency of Vitamin B12.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF(methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate that cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap.

Folate cycle provides a link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, where vitamin B12 deficiency causes a functional deficiency of folate.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?

1) Cell swelling
2) Karyolysis
3) Karyorrhexis
4) Pyknosis
questions.solution:
The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling → pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows:

Cytoplasmic changes -

  • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens
  • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by enzymatic degradation
  • Glossy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm

Nuclear changes -

  • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

questions.text: What type of cells are heart failure cells?
questions.solution:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin. 

The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

The given clinical scenario suggests alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes which are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency: 

  • It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum.
  • Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.
  • It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. 
  • Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

questions.text: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. 

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity (PAC / PRA).

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered sensorium, abnormal behavior, and hydrophobia. He was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient subsequently died and on autopsy, the following findings are seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these microscopic findings called?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of altered sensorium, abnormal behavior, and hydrophobia a few weeks after a dog bite are suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites that are usually devoid of inflammation.

The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods. 

 Image: Characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum

questions.text: An endoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with lower abdominal pain and severe diarrhea. Endoscopy revealed a cobblestone appearance. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliary cirrhosis.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following:

  • Uveitis
  • Migratory polyarthritis
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Clubbing of the fingertips
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis)
  • Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer)

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheeze. The image of a characteristic finding in the sputum is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL

Bleeding time - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - prolonged
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. 

Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively.

Clinical features of hemophilia:

  • Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities
  • Recurrent bleeding
  • Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor

It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT.

Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

Image: Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium.

Image: Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

questions.text: Given below is the histological slide demonstrating a renal pathology. Which of the following would be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, sometimes filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

  • Acute tubular necrosis: Focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis
  • Minimal change disease: Normal on light microscopy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Wire-loop lesions

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above image points show lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm which are characteristics of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

ALL is more common in childhood. The child had symptoms related to depression of marrow function including pallor, weight loss due to anaemia and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalised lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration.

questions.text: The structural representation and gross image of an emphysematous lung is shown below. What is the type of emphysema that is depicted?
questions.solution:
The given gross image is characteristic of centriacinar emphysema. Focal areas (arrows) show marked emphysematous damage, surrounded by relatively spared alveolar spaces.

In Panacinar emphysema all air spaces within acini are evenly enlarged.

In Paraseptal emphysema subpleural spaces are mainly affected.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance on culture as shown in the image below is due to ________
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic Pilot wheel appearance on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes Paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes.

On culture at 37 °C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage since 2 years. She has a history of asthma and allergy. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both the nasal cavities. A biopsy was taken from it and sent to the culture. The culture reveals the following appearance on microscopy as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the microscopic appearance is suggestive of fungal rhinosinusitis. The most probable causative organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.

The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus:

  • Vesicle is conical.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline.

 

 

Aspergillus niger

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer?

A. Before examining the patient
B. After examining the patient
C. After touching the patient's surroundings
D. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
You should use sanitiser before and after examining the patient and after touching the patient's surroundings.

The most significant precaution that is effective in preventing infection transmission is hand hygiene. This is achieved by washing hands with soap and water and/or by hand rubbing with alcohol or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizer. The most effective and least expensive way is by washing hands before and after any patient interaction.

Perform hand hygiene

  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • After barehanded touching of instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before and after treating each patient.
  • Before putting on gloves and again immediately after removing gloves.

First use soap and water when hands are visibly soiled (e.g., blood, body fluids). When they are not soiled, an alcohol-based hand rub may be used.

Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infective cardiac valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. The histopathological slide shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species with non-pigmented, narrow, septate, hyphae with branching at 45o (acute angle).

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection seen in the immunosuppressed hosts. Aspergillus has a tendency to invade blood vessels. Thus, widespread hematogenous dissemination with involvement of the heart valves and brain is common. Aspergillus form fruiting bodies and septate filaments, 5 to 10 µm thick, branching at acute angles (40 degrees). Aspergillus hyphae without the distinct fruiting body cannot be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

Rhinocerebral Aspergillus infection in immunosuppressed individuals resembles that caused by Mucormycoses (e.g., Mucor spp., Rhizopus spp.). (Option-A) Mucormycetes form broad ribbon-like non-septate pigmented hyphae of variable width (6 to 50 µm) with frequent right-angle branching, distinct from Aspergillus hyphae.

Option B: Disseminated fusariosis differs from disseminated aspergillosis as the former presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions are extremely common with fusariosis. No such history is given in the clinical stem. The organism is difficult to differentiate from Aspergillus species in tissues; thus, identification with culture is imperative.

Option C: Rhizopus shows aseptate hyphae with sporangium and sporangiophores. It is similar in appearance to that of mucormycosis.

questions.text: Which type of reaction is the Schultz-Dale phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Schultz–Dale phenomenon is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. 

It describes in-vitro contraction of smooth muscles that have been exposed to antigens, demonstrating immediate hypersensitivity reaction in some human and animal tissues.  

Other type I hypersensitivity reactions are the Prausnitz-Kustner reaction and the Theobald Smith phenomenon.

questions.text: Jumping gene is
questions.solution: Jumping gene is a transposon. They are genetic elements that contain several genes, including those necessary for their migration from one genetic locus to another.

questions.text: All of the following organism shows the following type of growth in culture media except
questions.solution:
The image shows swarming type of growth on blood agar. Swarming growth on culture media is exhibited by

  • Gram positive bacilli
    • Clostridium tetani
    • Bacillus cereus
  • Gram negative bacilli
    • Proteus mirabilis
    • Proteus vulgaris

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stain image of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic organism:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stain image suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Two distinct clinical patterns have been identified and designated as Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever, together known as legionellosis

Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough and dyspnea, rapidly progresses to pneumonia if left untreated, diarrhea and encephalopathy is also common. 

Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza like illness with fever, chills, myalgia and headache.

questions.text: A microbiologist working on influenza virus in a lab, observes reversal of hemagglutination. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface.

Influenza virus contains two surface antigens:

  • Hemagglutinin (HA) - causes RBC agglutination; facilitates viral entry into cells
  • Neuraminidase (NA) - an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs causing elution/reversal of hemagglutination. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE).

questions.text: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab.  On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you will expect to see in this stool sample?

choices.text: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux

questions.solution:
The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in the stool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The other stool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals.

The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only characteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from the nonpathogenic entamoeba.

Amoebic dysentery:

Clinically, it is insidious in onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, and fever are absent.

Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals and eosinophils are present.

Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen in stool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils.

The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals:

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with HIV is found to have a CD4+ count of 78cells/µL. Which of the following is not a function of these cells?
questions.solution:
CD4 helper T cells do not produce immunoglobulins.

Helper T cells are activated when an antigen-presenting cell expressing MHC-II binds to them. The activated helper T cell differentiates to produce effector Th cell and memory Th cell. Effector Th cells further differentiate to form Th1, Th2, and Th17. 

Functions of Helper T cells: 

  • Activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T cell
  • Regulation of monocyte-macrophage system
  • Activation of B cell to produce plasma cells
  • Production of interleukins 

 Immunoglobulins are produced by the plasma cells.

questions.text: The secretory component of IgA is formed by?

choices.text: Epithelial cells of lining mucosa only
Plasma cell and epithelial cells of lining mucosa

questions.solution:
The secretory component of IgA is formed by epithelial cells of lining mucosa.

 

Secretory IgA is a dimer formed by two monomer units joined together by a  J - chain and a secretory component (secretory piece). The secretory component is synthesized by epithelial cells to protect IgA from denaturation by bacterial proteases.

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

questions.text: Which of the following functions is exhibited by metoclopramide?

choices.text: Inhibits cholinergic smooth muscle stimulation in the gastrointestinal tract
Decreases the lower esophageal sphincter pressure

questions.solution:
Metoclopramide enhances gastrointestinal motility.

In GIT, acetylcholine increases gastrointestinal motility and increases lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone. Therefore, D2 receptor inhibition augments ACh release and enhances GI motility and LES tone. Metoclopramide inhibits gastric and intestinal D2 receptors. Metoclopramide’s action is generally confined to the upper digestive tract.

questions.text: All of the following are adverse effects of ropinirole except:
questions.solution:
Cardiac fibrosis is not seen with ropinirole. The adverse effects of ropinirole include nausea , drowsiness, and hallucinations.

Cardiac and pleural fibrosis is seen with pergolide which is also a dopamine agonist.

questions.text: The condition seen in the image below is associated with which of the following atypical antipsychotic agents?
questions.solution: The image shows the formation of a cataract, seen as an adverse effect of quetiapine.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding fosphenytoin?

choices.text: Fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin from protein-binding sites
Causes hyperphosphatemia in renal failure patients
ECG monitoring is not required when administering IV

questions.solution:
Fosphenytoin like phenytoin requires continuous ECG monitoring during IV infusion due to the risk of arrhythmias.

Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin. Fosphenytoin is also extensively protein bound, mainly albumin. This binding is saturable and fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin from protein-binding sites.

Hydrolysis of fosphenytoin yields phosphate, which increases the risk of hyperphosphatemia in patients with renal failure. It is contraindicated in patients with sinus bradycardia, sino-atrial block, second and third-degree A-V block.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
6-Mercaptopurine is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis.

6-Mercaptopurine is inactive in its parent form. It must be metabolized by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase to form monophosphate nucleotide 6-thioinosinic acid. This inhibits several enzymes of de novo purine nucleotide synthesis.

Other options:

Option B- Mitomycin acts as an alkylating agent and crosslinks DNA. It also generates free radicals which damage DNA.

Option C- Actinomycin causes single-strand breaks in DNA. It blocks RNA transcription.

Option D- L-Asparaginase causes the breakdown of asparagine and thus interferes with protein synthesis.

questions.text: A patient on treatment for glaucoma presented with complaints of floaters and flashing lights. He complains of seeing a dark grey curtain move across his field of vision. Which of the following can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of retinal detachment. It is associated with the use of miotics i.e., both cholinergic agonists and anticholinesterase agents.

Miotics produce ciliary body contraction which can lead to altered forces at the vitreous base resulting in retinal tears. Hence, they are to be used with extreme caution in patients who are at risk of developing retinal detachment.

questions.text: All of the following agents act by intracellular receptors except for ________
questions.solution:
Insulin receptors belong to the trans-membrane enzyme-linked receptor class.

Transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors

  • Large extracellular ligand-binding domain connected through a single transmembrane helical peptide chain to an intracellular subunit having enzymatic property.
  • Enzyme on the cytosolic side is usually a protein kinase (tyrosine) or membrane-bound GC.

Physiological ligands for transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors:

(Most are Growth factors and chemokines)

  • Receptor tyrosine kinases
    • Growth factors e.g. PDGF, EGF, VEGF
    • Insulin
  • Membrane-bound GC:
    • Natriuretic peptides
  • Receptor serine-threonine kinases:
    • TGF-beta 

Thyroid hormones, vitamin D, and steroids act via intracellular receptors (Options A, B, and D).

questions.text: A 5-year-old child requires bronchodilator therapy. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

  • Pressurized metered-dose inhalers - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of a drug
  • Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children <7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 
  • Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -
    • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
    • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause:
questions.solution:
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause metabolic alkalosis. They cause metabolic acidosis due to increased bicarbonate excretion.

Increased bicarbonate excretion causes urinary alkalinization (Option A and B). Increased delivery of Na+ to distal tubules causes increased K+ excretion (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following is a third-generation cephalosporin that can be given orally?
questions.solution:
Cefixime is a third-generation oral cephalosporin.
