questions.text: LMWH is given by which route?
questions.solution:
LMWH is given by the subcutaneous route.

Heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), and fondaparinux are not absorbed through GI mucosa and must be given parenterally.

LMWH and fondaparinux are given subcutaneously.

Heparin can be given through intravenous infusion and subcutaneous routes.

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction asks you why he is being prescribed aspirin. You tell him it prevents the formation of clots which reduces the risk of MI. Formation of which of the following eicosanoids is blocked by aspirin for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Thromboxane A2 is a pro-aggregatory eicosanoid whose formation requires the activity of COX enzyme. Aspirin blocks this step, thus reducing the chances of clot formation.

Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and amplifies the signal of more potent platelet agonists, such as thrombin and ADP.

Related Pearl: Prostaglandins effect on platelet action

Anti-aggregatory prostaglandins:

  • PGI2
  • PGD2

Pro-aggregatory prostaglandins:

  • Thromboxane A2
  • PGH2
  • PGG2

Variable effects are seen with PGE2

questions.text: The most appropriate description of vasomotor reversal of Dale is

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.

Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces α1 mediated rise in BP followed by β2 mediated fall in BP.

Vasomotor reversal of Dale: Administration of epinephrine after administration of α blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β mediated response is seen, i.e., fall in BP.

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

choices.text: Police not under rank of  sub inspector

questions.solution:
In the case of civil negligence, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence.

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. What is the maximum time by which the practitioner can take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
A vaginal swab of a rape victim demonstrates spermatozoa if the vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours after an assault.

However vaginal swab can be taken within 96 hours to demonstrate semen.

Evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing can be collected even after 96 hours.

questions.text: As per The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, Induction of MTP in a  mentally ill, rape victim is allowed until what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill 2020, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill or rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks. 

 

Salient features of amendments:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors) etc.
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit not to apply in cases of substantial foetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorised in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptive has been extended to women and her partner.

 

Note: The bill has been passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act 1971

Indications :

  • Therapeutic : When continuation of pregnancy endangers the life of the woman, or may injure her physical or mental health. 
  • Eugenic : The risk of child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality. This includes first trimester viral infections, maternal drug intake (thalidomide, cortisone, antimitotics), xray or radioisotope treatment of the mother, insanity of parents and viral hepatitis.
  • Humanitarian : Pregnancy resulted from rape.
  • Social : Pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives. 

Rules :

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government recognised hospital.
  • Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is a minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband is not necessary.
  • If the woman is not willing, abortion can not be performed on the request of the husband alone.
  • The woman need not produce proof of her age. The statement of the woman that she is over 18 years of age is accepted.
  • It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.
  • Professional secrecy has to be maintained.
  • If the period of pregnancy is below 20 weeks, it can be terminated on the opinion of a single doctor.
  • If the period of pregnancy is between 20-24 weeks, two doctors must opine that there is an indication. Once there is an indication, the termination can be done by any one doctor.
  • In an emergency, the termination can be done by a single doctor, even without the required training, even after 20 weeks, without consulting a second doctor, in a private hospital which is not recognised. 
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years.

Confidentiality :

The head of the hospital must maintain a register for recording the details of MTP. This register is a secret document which should be kept under safe custody for five years, and each patient is given a reference number. The name of the patient should not be entered anywhere, any case sheet or operation theatre register or any other record.

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the above X-ray image of the wrist and hand all the carpal bones are seen and the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft, suggesting an age of 12 to 15 years.

Among the given options, 13 years is the most appropriate.

questions.text: The wound in the given image is most likely to have been produced by?
questions.solution:
The image shows 'tram-line' bruising, most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle. 

Tram-line bruising:

  • When the skin surface is struck by a rod or rectangular sectioned object such as a cane or lath, the consequent bruising may be of the ‘tram-line’ or ‘railway line’ type.
  • The mechanism of this double line is that the weapon sinks into the skin on impact so that the edges drag the skin downwards and the traction tears the marginal blood vessels. The centre compresses the skin, which, in the absence of underlying bone, causes little or no damage to the vessels.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is the Barberio test.

It is used to detect seminal fluid. When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Florence test: 

  • Used to detect: semen
  • Stain used: 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water)
  • Finding: If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately

Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • Used to detect: bloodstains
  • Stain used: Takayama reagent
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes

Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • Used to detect: bloodstains
  • Stain used: glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A woman was drugged with a substance, which was slipped into her coffee without her knowledge by a man at her workplace. The man confessed that he tried to make her notice him by adding a love philter to her coffee. Which of the following would he have used?
questions.solution:
A love philter is a magical potion that is supposed to make the person who receives the potion love the one who gave it. These are usually aphrodisiacs.

Some aphrodisiacs that are used as love philter are:

  • Cantharides
  • Arsenic
  • Alcohol
  • Opium
  • Cocaine
  • Cannabis

The use of a love philter might lead to accidental poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom?
questions.solution:
Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom. 

The venom is a clear, colorless, proteinous toxalbumen, having a hemolytic and neurotoxic effect. Its toxicity is more than that of snakes, but only a small quantity is injected. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local and simulates the viper snake bite. The scorpion sting will have only one hole in the center of the reddened area. The extremity will have edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours.

The symptoms produced by a neurotoxic venom are similar to a cobra bite. There is usually no marked reaction in the local area. Nausea, vomiting, extreme restlessness, fever, various types of paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, convulsions, coma, respiratory depression, and death may occur within hours from pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.

Prazosin can counteract the alpha-adrenergic effects of autonomic stimulation, such as hypertension.

questions.text: Human skeletal remains were found in an abandoned basement in Wuhan. Which of the following would indicate that the victim was a Caucasian?

choices.text: Lack of the third upper molar

questions.solution:
Carabelli’s cusps are most commonly seen only in Caucasian races and rare in the other major racial groups. These are small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars.

The image below shows Carabelli’s cusps seen in Caucasian races.

Features of mongoloid dentition include:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a central depression
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Taurodontism (bull-tooth) - Pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar

The image below shows shovel-shaped upper central incisors seen in mongoloid races compared to non-shovel shaped incisors:

questions.text: As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service  Institutions Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered as:
questions.solution:
As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service Institutions (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property) Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered a cognizable and non-bailable offense.  

As per this law, enacted by many Indian states, violence against registered medical practitioners, registered nurses, medical and nursing students, and paramedical and other auxiliary workers carries a penalty of imprisonment and fine.  

Violence means activities of causing any harm, injury, or endangering the life or intimidation, obstruction, or hindrance to any medicare service person while discharging their duty in the medicare service institution or causing damage or loss to the property.

The period of imprisonment may extend from 3 to 10 years in certain states.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.solution:
In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane.

Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergency life-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre. Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy.

Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane.

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Rinne's test is positive on both ears implying that there is no conductive hearing loss. But there could still be sensorineural hearing loss in either or both ears.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates either right-sided conductive hearing loss or left-sided sensorineural hearing loss. Since there is no conductive deafness which was inferred from Rinnes's test, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor scholastic performance?
questions.solution:
The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance. 

Related Pearl: Types of tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: A teenage boy presents to you with recurrent epistaxis and hearing loss. On examination, he has a frog-face deformity and conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Investigation of choice to diagnose this condition is contrast enhancement CT scan (CECT).

MRI scan can be used complementary to CT to see soft tissue extensions of the tumor.

Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor, its vascularity, and feeding vessels which mostly come from the external carotid system. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time to decrease bleeding at operation.

A biopsy is contraindicated in this condition as it can lead to massive hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old ironsmith came to the ENT clinic with complaints of dry nose, nasal crusting and bleeding on removal of the crusts. A diagnosis of rhinitis sicca was made. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: More common in people working in hot, dry, dusty surroundings
Antibiotic & steroid ointment is used for treatment

questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca affects the anterior 1/3rd of the nose since this part is exposed to the effect of the dry, dusty air.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is usually confined to the anterior third of the nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands.

Treatment consists of correcting occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment with an antibiotic and steroid combination to the affected part.

questions.text: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. 

Clinical features of DNS:

  • Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation
  • Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the nose
  • Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses
  • Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa
  • Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on roomier side
  • Frequent middle ear infections
  • Association with external deformities

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with sweating over the right cheek while eating. She underwent parotid surgery 6 months back. The finding of the starch iodine test is shown in the image. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

choices.text: Aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic sweat glands
Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with greater auricular nerve
Aberrant reinnervation of sympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with parasympathetic sweat glands
Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with auriculotemporal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is Frey’s syndrome or gustatory sweating. It is due to aberrant reinnervation (or cross innervation) of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands.

The patient usually presents with sweating and flushing over the parotid area during mastication. This usually occurs after parotid surgery.

It is diagnosed by Minor's test or starch iodine test. The affected area is painted with iodine and is allowed to dry. Then dry corn starch is applied. The starch turns blue on exposure to iodine in the presence of sweat.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck.  The features include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In an acute abscess,  air-fluid levels can be seen.

questions.text: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS)

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome

  • Occurs due to the third window effect that gets created because of the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal.
  • Endolymph in the labyrinthine system move in relation to sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system.
  • Diagnosed in middle-aged individuals.
  • Noise or pressure-induced dizziness ,chronic imbalance, avoidance of noisy environments.
  • Gaze-evoked tinnitus and/or hyperacusis. 
  • Tulio phenomenon(sound or pressure-induced vestibular activation).
  • Fistula test is positive(Hennebert Sign)
  • Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect
  • Treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms else conservative medical management.

questions.text: In stapedotomy, piston is placed between ______
questions.solution:
• Stapedotomy is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound.
  • For this reason the piston replaces the removed stapes superstructure.
  • It is placed between incus and oval window in the hole made on the footplate.

questions.text: The most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

questions.text: Pathognomonic of chronic maxillary sinusitis is
questions.solution:
Anterior rhinoscopy in chronic maxillary sinusitis shows discharge in middle meatus which is mucoid or mucopurulent. It is pathognomonic finding in maxillary sinusitis.
Option b: History of early morning headache is seen in acute frontal sinusitis.

questions.text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta/hypernasality will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.

It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. The defect is in the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities.

Common causes are:

  1. Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  2. Congenitally short soft palate
  3. Submucous palate
  4. Large nasopharynx
  5. Cleft of soft palate
  6. Paralysis of soft palate
  7. Post adenoidectomy
  8. Oronasal fistula
  9. Familial speech pattern
  10. Habitual speech pattern.

questions.text: Most common cause for bilateral Recurrent laryngeal Nerve paralysis_____
questions.solution:
Surgical trauma is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures

A 20-year retrospective study of causes of vocal fold immobility shows that neck surgery has become the most common cause of vocal fold paralysis over the past 10 years.

Note : Previously, extralaryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included Lung (50%), Oesophagus, Thyroid, Larynx.

questions.text: The following procedure is commonly carried out using:
questions.solution:
The procedure is proof puncture (antral lavage). Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula are used for the puncture of the lateral wall of the inferior meatus, at a point 1.5–2.0 cm from the anterior end of inferior turbinate and near the attachment of concha with the lateral wall.

Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with red arrow
questions.solution:
The structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina. 

The outer plexiform layer (outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and the inner nuclear layer. This layer stains lightly. This region consists only of nerve fibers that form a plexus. The axons of rods and cones synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells in this layer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: The rigid IOL is made up of ______.
questions.solution:
Depending on the type of material of manufacturing, 3 types of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOLs) are available:

  • Rigid IOLs
    • The modern one-piece rigid IOLs are made entirely from polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).
  • Foldable IOLs
    • To be implanted through a small incision after phacoemulsification
    • Are made of silicone, hydrogel, acrylic, and collamer
  • Rollable IOLs
    • Are ultra-thin IOLs
    • Are implanted through a 1-mm incision after microincision cataract surgery technique.
    • Are made of acrylic

questions.text: The cherry red spot seen in the image below is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows a cherry-red spot, which is a feature of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

Pathophysiology of the cherry-red spot:

A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.

Risk factors of CRAO:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Trauma

Clinical features of CRAO:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema: The whole retina looks white in color.
  • Marked attenuation of arteries: thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in the artery and veins: cattle-track appearance
  • Cherry-red spot
  • Hollenhorst plaques - cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the intraocular pressure (IOP) by intravenous mannitol or ocular massage. The time limit is only 4 to 6 hours.

questions.text: The most common late complication following cataract surgery is ___________.
questions.solution: The most common late complication following cataract surgery is posterior capsule opacification.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is neuroblastoma.

Most common cause:

Unilateral proptosis Bilateral proptosis
In children: Orbital cellulitis In children: Neuroblastoma and leukemia (chloroma)
In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Image: Bilateral proptosis

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye.

Treatment of dry eye include medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to you with the complaints of foreign body sensation, irritation, and lacrimation in the right eye.  During the evaluation, you notice the following findings with normal lid margins. This condition is known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the above image is suggestive of Trichiasis.

Trichiasis refers to inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensation and photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation.  On examination, one or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea is seen. Conjunctiva may be congested.

Treatment includes:

  • Epilation: Mechanical removal with forceps
  • Electrolysis: Method of destroying the lash follicle by electric current.
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction.

questions.text: On entering the Ophthalmology OPD for the first time, you notice multiple patients being examined using the following instrument. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a slit lamp. Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is the ideal method to visualize the fundus, especially for observing the optic disc changes seen in glaucoma.

The lenses used are as follows:

  • Contact type: Goldmann three-mirror contact lens, modified Koeppe lens
  • Non-contact type: Convex lens à+60D, +78D, +90D (best lens)
  • Hruby lens: planoconcave lens with dioptric power of -58.6 D.

Option B: The image given below shows a visual field analyzer

Option C: The image given below shows a keratometer

Option A: The image given below shows an ophthalmoscope

questions.text: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history of watering  and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
questions.solution:
The image shows right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage with topical antibiotics.

More than 90% of patients with congenital nasolacrimal obstruction undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

Treatment depends on the age of the child:

  • Less than 9 months
    • Massaging (Crigler’s massage, which increases the hydrostatic pressure)
    • Antibiotics eye drops
  • 9 months to 4 years
    • Probing
  • Older children (> 4 years):
    • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)
    • In DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.
    • DCR gives the best result.

questions.text: Which among the following is called malignant  glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ciliary block glaucoma is also called as malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma.

It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against lens/ intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of vitreous. Hence, aqueous starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. 

Clinical features :

  • Persistent flat AC
  • Negative Seidel’s test
  • Raised intraocular pressure (IOP)

Treatment

  • Atropine (malignant glaucoma also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used), timolol, acetazolamide
  • Nd:Yag laser hyaloidotomy: making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Identify the pathology indicated in the given image.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts "sauce and cheese" retinopathy, which is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Central CMV retinitis

  • Dense, white areas of retinal necrosis
  • Retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis
  • Pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance

Peripheral CMV retinitis

  • Less demarcated
  • Infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.

CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with HIV.

questions.text: In which surgery would you use the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: The image shows a Ziegler knife, which is used to open the lens capsule and aspirate the lens material in congenital cataract surgeries.

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about health education is false?

choices.text: It aids in developing a reflective behavior

questions.solution:
Health education appeals to people’s reason. Health propaganda appeals to people’s emotions.

Health Education vs. Propaganda:

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge & Skills Knowledge and skills are actively acquired Knowledge is instilled in the mind
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behavior- trains people to use judgement before acting Reflexive behavior- aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Process Behavior centered Information centered

questions.text: You have been tasked with studying the age and sex structure of a population with high rates of female infanticide. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use?
questions.solution:
The age and sex structure of a population may be best represented using a population pyramid.

It is a histogram that shows the distribution of ages across a population. It is divided down the center between male and female members of the population.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text:
Which of the following should not be incinerated?
  1. Sharps and waste with heavy metals
  2. Reactive chemical waste
  3. Specimens of microorganisms
  4. Pressurized gas containers
  5. Live or attenuated vaccines
questions.solution:
Specimens of microorganisms and live or attenuated vaccines can be incinerated.

Wastes that should not be incinerated are:

  • Sharps
  • Pressurized gas containers
  • Reactive chemical waste
  • Waste with heavy metals like mercury and cadmium
  • PVC
  • Photographic or radiographic waste

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with gradually progressive muscle weakness and leg spasms for 2 months. He says that he had been consuming an inexpensive dal resembling red gram for the past 2 years. Pure motor paresis was seen on examination. Which of the following could have prevented this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of neurolathyrism. It can be prevented and treated by the administration of vitamin C at doses of 500-1000 mg.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram.

BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy

(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites

questions.text: Matching is done for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors.

Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results.

questions.text: Community or village health guides are selected by:
questions.solution:
Village health guides (VHGs) are selected by the medical officer-in-charge (MO).

2-3 candidates are put forward by the community for the position of a VHG. The MO selects one of them after consultation with the block development officer and field staff.

questions.text: Who among the following is not a target for primary prevention?
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic patients are the target population for secondary prevention but not for primary prevention.

Primary prevention is implemented before the onset of the disease. Hence, all patients including asymptomatic ones are not included in the target group.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of maternal deaths in India?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of maternal deaths in India is hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: What is potential support ratio?

choices.text: Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per child below 15 years or less
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older person aged 65 or more
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged >65 and younger person aged < 15
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged > 60 and younger person aged <15

questions.solution: The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. It is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Human Development Index (HDI)?
questions.solution:
HDI dimensions or components are longevity, knowledge and income.

Indicators used in HDI are life expectancy at birth, literacy and enrolment, and GNI per capita in purchasing power parity (PPP) US$.

 

  • Final HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value
  • HDI can be used to compare living standards in different countries.
  • Indian HDI is 0.640

India currently ranks 134 (HDI is 0.644) on the 2022 Human developmental Index.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

questions.text: How many people does one sub-center in a hilly or remote area cater to?
questions.solution:
A sub-center caters to a population of 5000 in general areas and 3000 in hilly or remote areas.

Services provided at sub-centers:

  • Maternal and child health, family planning
  • Counseling for abortion and adolescent health care
  • Water quality monitoring and sanitation promotion
  • Assistance to school health services
  • Field visits and treating minor ailments
  • Training of ASHA and birth attendants
  • Disease surveillance and National Health Programme functions

questions.text: Which food item among the options given has the highest Net Protein Utilisation value?
questions.solution:
The Net Protein Utilisation value of the food items given in decreasing order is: 

Egg (100) > Meat (80) > Milk (75) > Rice (65) > Soya (61)

If the NPU is low, the protein requirement is high.

The NPU of protein of Indian diets is between 50 and 80.

questions.text: An infant of 9 months is brought to the OPD with no history of previous vaccination. The mother is however adamant and is allowing you to inject the baby with one vaccine only. Which of the following vaccines would you chose to administer in this situation?
questions.solution: In this situation, the measles vaccine should be administered subcutaneously and OPV and Vitamin A should be given orally. At 9 months of age, it is a priority to give the Measles vaccine.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines is not covered in the programme mentioned below?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush does not include a typhoid vaccine.

Eight vaccines were included in it previously (Diphtheria, Whooping cough, Tetanus, Poliomyelitis, Tuberculosis, Measles, Hemophilus influenza type B and Hepatitis B)

In 2016 four new vaccines were added (Japanese B Encephalitis, Rubella, Rotavirus, Injectable polio vaccine).

Now, under Mission Indradhanush all the vaccines provided under the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) are administered to children and pregnant women.

Through UIP, Government of India is providing vaccination free of cost against vaccine-preventable diseases include diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, polio, measles, a severe form of childhood tuberculosis, hepatitis B, meningitis and pneumonia (Hemophilus influenza type B infections), Japanese encephalitis (JE) in JE endemic districts with the introduction of newer vaccines such as rotavirus vaccine, IPV, adult JE vaccine, pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV)  and measles-rubella (MR) vaccine in UIP/national immunization program.

This mission was launched by Union health minister on 25 December 2014.
Immunization drive will be for 7 days starting from the 7th of every month.

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The school health programs are managed by the primary health centre (PHC).

The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services. Since the general health services are administered through PHCs, school health programs are also managed by the PHCs under their jurisdiction.

The School Health Committee advocated the formation of school health committees at the village level, block level, district level, state level, and national level. The National School Health Council will be an advisory and coordinating body.

PHCs provide the following school health services:

  • Screening of general health assessment of anemia/nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up, physical disabilities, learning disorders, and behavior problems, etc.
  • Basic medicines for common ailments
  • Immunization 
  • Micronutrient (Vitamin A, iron, and folic acid) management
  • Deworming 
  • Mid-day meal

 Note: National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools has recently been renamed Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN).

questions.text: Most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available is considered to be ________
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal.

Controlled Tipping:

  • It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal in available land
  • Waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted and covered with Earth at the end of the day
  • This method is also called as sanitary landfill
  • Methods used for controlled tipping are the trench method, the ramp method and the area method
  • Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

questions.text: Continuous exposure to sound above _________ dB can cause permanent hearing loss
questions.solution: • Continuous exposure to sound above 100 dB can cause permanent hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following practices is covered under the COPRA act?
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are:

  • Right to safety
  • Right to be informed
  • Right to be heard
  • Right to choose
  • Right to seek redressal
  • Right to consumer education

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a ceramic factory. What particle size of the dust inhaled would you be most concerned about?
questions.solution: Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called pneumoconioses.
